title: What are the units for q in the equation q=mcΔT? - Quora

response.answer_text: Usually, mcΔT = ΔH, if you’re a chemist and the units will be kcal. If you’re an engineer, you may think of kilo-joules and mcΔT= q (kJ). But there’s really no difference, as 4.184 kjoules = 1 kcal, and even if you use energy/mole, you get the same ratio of kJ/kcal = 4.184 = J/cal The easiest way I’ve found to keep this all together is “unit analysis” so m (g) * c(energy/g.T) * (T) gives an answer that is always in energy units (ΔT has units of temperature) and if you need energy/mole, you can use mole/g * m(g), and c (energy/mole.T). To mop up, don’t get tangled with units of T, by allowing a value for c (…/F) to be used if ΔT has units of C or K. Make sure the heat capacity T units match the thermometer T units.

The beauty of equations like that is that almost any unit can be used as long as you include a conversion… This is the heat transfer formula, so q is usually measured in Joules, and c is measured in C. (Celsius) But if you want to use F (Fahrenheit) instead, fine… but you have to include the conversion to C. (F - 32 * 5/9)
